Where frowns yon hill with beetling brow,</br>O'er the pale water's eddying round,</br>Shall thy funereal honours grow,</br>And mark the wild, deserted ground.
From all their lonely haunts of woe,</br>The fabled forms of air shall glance,</br>Mount the low-murmuring stream below,</br>Or on the whirlwind's wing advance;—
Here fond remembrance ling'ring still</br>On friendship's heart thy praise portray,</br>Maz'd rapture pour the trembling trill,</br>And join thine own ecstatic lay.
Peace, a cherubic maid, shall come,</br>And Science sage, a pilgrim old,</br>Bliss beneath her aromatic bloom,</br>And Fancy her full flowers unfold.
The linnet here shall build her nest,</br>To harmonize thy silent vale,</br>And, plac'd on thy bold, lifeless breast,</br>The sad harp court the passing gale.
Oft shall the Fates, terrific, throng</br>The blasted heath's wide, trackless space,</br>The clouds shall moan with sternest song,</br>And yells of mourning drear the place.
The shepherd, while, with pliant rod,</br>He hangs suspended o'er the wave,</br>Shall pause to mark thy still abode,</br>And crown with moss thy silent grave—
Shall weep — till, rushing on the wind,</br>Mysterious squadrons crowd the sky,</br>Heave a deep, dismal dirge, combin'd,</br>And bid the mortal miscreant fly.
True Poesy's majestic queen</br>Shall stalk around thy holy clay,</br>Defend from blights the sacred green,</br>And scare the Elves of night away.</br>
